Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is your engine performance problem?
Description: Vacuum is responsible for drawing air into the cylinders, it is also responsible for the operation of emissions system, braking system and cruise control system components. Vacuum is transfered through a complex system of rubber hoses and/or plastic tubes. The engine creates a great deal of heat and over time can cause the rubber and plastic hoses to dry out and leak. A vacuum leak can be elusive and take a long time to detect. Common symptoms of a vacuum leak include; vehicle idle fluctuation, hard brake pedal, and a hissing noise heard under the hood.
InspectionList: 1) Open the hood and locate the vacuum hoses. Some Vehicles are equipped with a vacuum hose diagram that can be found under the hood, if not a repair manual is the best way to find were all the vacuum hoses are located for your vehicle. Vacuum hoses are rubber hoses or plastic tubes that operate and control systems such as, emissions,  power brakes, and cruise control. Vacuum leaks can also cause idling and drivability problems.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is your engine performance problem?
Description: Vacuum is responsible for drawing air into the cylinders, it is also responsible for the operation of emissions system, braking system and cruise control system components. Vacuum is transfered through a complex system of rubber hoses and/or plastic tubes. The engine creates a great deal of heat and over time can cause the rubber and plastic hoses to dry out and leak. A vacuum leak can be elusive and take a long time to detect. Common symptoms of a vacuum leak include; vehicle idle fluctuation, hard brake pedal, and a hissing noise heard under the hood.
InspectionList: 2) It may be necessary to use a flashlight in order inspect possible damaged vacuum hoses. Check the vacuum hose that leads to the brake booster for damage or if it is loose.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is your engine performance problem?
Description: Vacuum is responsible for drawing air into the cylinders, it is also responsible for the operation of emissions system, braking system and cruise control system components. Vacuum is transfered through a complex system of rubber hoses and/or plastic tubes. The engine creates a great deal of heat and over time can cause the rubber and plastic hoses to dry out and leak. A vacuum leak can be elusive and take a long time to detect. Common symptoms of a vacuum leak include; vehicle idle fluctuation, hard brake pedal, and a hissing noise heard under the hood.
InspectionList: 3) Continue to inspect for cracked or broken vacuum hoses throughout the engine compartment. Look for worn or disconnected hoses or tubes.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is your engine performance problem?
Description: Vacuum is responsible for drawing air into the cylinders, it is also responsible for the operation of emissions system, braking system and cruise control system components. Vacuum is transfered through a complex system of rubber hoses and/or plastic tubes. The engine creates a great deal of heat and over time can cause the rubber and plastic hoses to dry out and leak. A vacuum leak can be elusive and take a long time to detect. Common symptoms of a vacuum leak include; vehicle idle fluctuation, hard brake pedal, and a hissing noise heard under the hood.
InspectionList: 4) Use a can of carburetor cleaner to spray suspecting hoses. With the vehicle running, spray the hose. If the hose has a leak it will pull the carburetor cleaner in and stabilize the idle for a brief time. If changes are heard after spraying the vacuum hose, it is necessary to replace that particular hose.

Description: If the ignition key was left on (engine off), it can cause the coil to heat up and melt some of the internal components. This would leave a permanent open circuit and inhibit the coil from outputting a spark.
InspectionList: 1) Open the hood and locate the vehicles ignition coil.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is your engine performance problem?

InspectionList: 2) Connect the spark tester to the ignition coil output.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is your engine performance problem?

InspectionList: 3) Crank the engine.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:

InspectionList: 4) Follow a wiring diagram to determine if the coil is power or ground side controlled. If controlled by ground connect the test light clip to power side of battery and touch the test light to the negative side of the coil.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is your engine performance problem?
Description: Gas go bad overtime, certain components of gas can vaporize over time and have a negatively impact how efficiently the gas burns in your engine. Oxidization and water contamination will also contribute to the gas going bad.
InspectionList: 1) To inspect your fuel system, drive your vehicle to see how it performs. Your vehicle should drive smoothly, accelerate with ease, and go up and down through the speed limits easily. The mileage on your vehicle and the condition of the engine will also have an influence on how the vehicle drives.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is your engine performance problem?
Description: Gas go bad overtime, certain components of gas can vaporize over time and have a negatively impact how efficiently the gas burns in your engine. Oxidization and water contamination will also contribute to the gas going bad.
InspectionList: 2) If you have a clear fuel filter, inspect the color of the fuel. If the fuel is dark, the fuel system needs to be flushed.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is your engine performance problem?
Description: Gas go bad overtime, certain components of gas can vaporize over time and have a negatively impact how efficiently the gas burns in your engine. Oxidization and water contamination will also contribute to the gas going bad.
InspectionList: 3) Open the fuel fill cap and try to smell the fuel. If the level is low remove the Fuel Filter (see instructions for fuel filter replacing) and smell the fuel. If the fuel smells like varnish, the fuel is bad.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is your engine performance problem?
Description: Gas go bad overtime, certain components of gas can vaporize over time and have a negatively impact how efficiently the gas burns in your engine. Oxidization and water contamination will also contribute to the gas going bad.
InspectionList: 4) You may also want to inspect the condition of the fuel lines and fuel tank. If you notice that fuel lines are cracked (allowing water/condensation to enter the fuel lines) or that the fuel tank is rusted or has cracks, you will want to replace these parts.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is your engine performance problem?
Specific Answer: Carburetor engine stalling and running rough at low RPM
Description: Carburetors will wear over time due to the heat and driving habit abuse. They begin to leak, internally fail and will cause drivability problems until fixed.
InspectionList: 1) Locate the carburetor and remove the air cleaner assembly to gain full access to the carburetor.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is your engine performance problem?
Specific Answer: Carburetor engine stalling and running rough at low RPM
Description: Carburetors will wear over time due to the heat and driving habit abuse. They begin to leak, internally fail and will cause drivability problems until fixed.
InspectionList: 2) With the engine running at idle, inspect for fuel leaks around the seals of the carburetor.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is your engine performance problem?
Specific Answer: Carburetor engine stalling and running rough at low RPM
Description: Carburetors will wear over time due to the heat and driving habit abuse. They begin to leak, internally fail and will cause drivability problems until fixed.
InspectionList: 3) With the engine still running at idle, adjust the air and fuel mixture screws.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is your engine performance problem?
Specific Answer: Carburetor engine stalling and running rough at low RPM
Description: Carburetors will wear over time due to the heat and driving habit abuse. They begin to leak, internally fail and will cause drivability problems until fixed.
InspectionList: 4) Shut the engine off and inspect the bowl of the carburetor. Signs of carbon build up indicate a rich fuel condition typically caused by internal damage in the carburetor.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is your engine performance problem?
Description: Dirty fuel or rich running fuel systems will cause excessive carbon build up that will eventually cause a rough running symptom. Throttle plates will not be able to close correctly and will lead to issues with the air-to-fuel mixtures that will affect the idle.
InspectionList: 1) Open your hood and locate your engines throttle body.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is your engine performance problem?
Description: Dirty fuel or rich running fuel systems will cause excessive carbon build up that will eventually cause a rough running symptom. Throttle plates will not be able to close correctly and will lead to issues with the air-to-fuel mixtures that will affect the idle.
InspectionList: 2) Remove the air intake duct at the throttle body.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is your engine performance problem?
Description: Dirty fuel or rich running fuel systems will cause excessive carbon build up that will eventually cause a rough running symptom. Throttle plates will not be able to close correctly and will lead to issues with the air-to-fuel mixtures that will affect the idle.
InspectionList: 3) Inspect the throttle body ports for carbon build up. Throttle bore wear is also common after long periods of time and throttle body assemblies will need to be replaced if worn.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is your engine performance problem?
Description: Fuel pumps are constantly operating to supply the correct amount of fuel pressure to keep the vehicle running properly. Normal wear shortens the lifespan of the fuel pump. The fuel keeps the fuel pump lubricated and cooled, so running a fuel pump with low or no gas and starving it from fluid may lead to overheating and eventually burn the fuel pump out.
InspectionList: 1) Check the fuel cap, fuel tank, and fuel lines for leaks. Repair all leaks before proceeding.

InspectionList: 2) On most late model vehicles, the electric fuel pump is located in the fuel tank. Remove the gas cap so that you can hear the fuel pump start.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is your engine performance problem?
Description: The check engine light is an indicator that notifies the driver of a system malfunction. The ECM (On-board compurter) stores trouble codes in its memory and will trigger the "check engine" or "service engine soon" light when it surfaces. In order to determine the problem, a technician must use a Diagnostic Scan tool (Diagnostic computer) to access the trouble codes. The tool allows the technician to display all sensor values and codes to determine the best approach for repairs.
InspectionList: 1) Verify that the check engine light is on while the vehicle is running.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:

In order to determine the problem, a technician must use a Diagnostic Scan tool (Diagnostic computer) to access the trouble codes. The tool allows the technician to display all sensor values and codes to determine the best approach for repairs.
InspectionList: 2) Turn off the engine and locate the data link connector (DLC). For OBD-2, the 16 pin DLC is usually found underneath the driver's side dash, either on the left or right side of the steering column.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is your engine performance problem?
Description: The purpose of the air filter is to catch any debris before it enters the engine. Over time the air filter can become clogged with dirt and restrict the flow of air to the engine. A dirty air filter and old spark plugs will have a negative effect on the engines performance. Spark plugs should work properly to provide the best possible spark to burn the gas in the combustion chambers.
InspectionList: 1) Open the hood and locate the vehicles air filter, drive belts, distributor cap, spark plugs, and spark plug wires. These are parts that are most commonly replaced during an engine tune up.

InspectionList: 2) Remove the air filter from the air box that it may be held in and check for dirt and debris built up on the air filter.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Are you having a problem with your wheels or tires?
Asks: What type of problem are you having with your wheels?
Symptom: Wheel feels loose or wobbles while driving
Description: Wheel Lug nuts and studs are a very important part of a vehicle, they hold the wheels on. Whenever the wheels are removed it is important for safety and ride that the lug nuts are torqued back to the right specifications. Many technicians use just there drive air gun when tightening wheels, while it can tighten the lug nuts down fast it can also over tighten them making it extremely difficult to remove the lug nuts the next time. There is nothing worse than having a flat tire and not being able to remove the wheel to put your spare on. The reverse is also true, while air powered or electric powered tools are strong they can lose power, if the air pressure or battery power are too low for the tool it may not tighten the lug nuts enough. This is why lug nut torque should always be checked by hand. It is a good idea to ask the technicians to check your wheel torque by hand whenever you have work done to your vehicle.
InspectionList: 1) Wheel Lug nuts are responsible for holding your wheels to the vehicle. On some vehicles the lugs nuts are exposed and easy to get to. Some wheels may have a hub cap or center rim cap that cover the lug nuts, Using a flat head pop off the hub cap or rim center cap.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Are you having a problem with your wheels or tires?
Asks: What type of problem are you having with your wheels?
Symptom: Wheel feels loose or wobbles while driving
Description: Wheel Lug nuts and studs are a very important part of a vehicle, they hold the wheels on. Whenever the wheels are removed it is important for safety and ride that the lug nuts are torqued back to the right specifications. Many technicians use just there drive air gun when tightening wheels, while it can tighten the lug nuts down fast it can also over tighten them making it extremely difficult to remove the lug nuts the next time. There is nothing worse than having a flat tire and not being able to remove the wheel to put your spare on. The reverse is also true, while air powered or electric powered tools are strong they can lose power, if the air pressure or battery power are too low for the tool it may not tighten the lug nuts enough. This is why lug nut torque should always be checked by hand. It is a good idea to ask the technicians to check your wheel torque by hand whenever you have work done to your vehicle.
InspectionList: 2) The wheel lug nuts should be tight on the wheel and the wheel should be flat against the hub. Make sure all the lug nuts are accounted for, and for obvious damage. Check the lug nuts by trying to turn them by hand if you are able to twist any of them at all then the lug nuts are loose and you will want to further inspect to find out why the lug nuts are loose, and make the necessary repairs. If all of the lug nuts seem tight to the touch, try using your factory tire iron, it is located with the vehicles jack, check the owners manual for location. Then using the tire iron turn the lug nuts clock wise, they should be tight, if you have little trouble turning any of the lug nuts one quarter to half of a full rotation then you should check all of the wheels for safety to make sure they are on correctly.

Description: Wheel bearings can wear over time because of dirt, lack of lubrication, and improper adjustment. A loose or worn wheel bearing can cause noises and vibrations. It can also affect vehicle handling, braking, and tire wear.
InspectionList: 1) Secure the vehicle on a level surface.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:

InspectionList: 5) Next, grab the tire at the twelve o'clock and six o'clock position. Try and wobble the tire and wheel back and forth. There should be very little play when doing this. If there is too much play, the wheel bearings could be worn or out of adjustment.

Description: Valve stems are made out of rubber and are prone to dry out and become brittle. Improperly installed valve stems can also allow air to leak out of the tire. The shrader valve may also become loose, which is a smaller valve inside the stem that holds the air pressure.
InspectionList: 1) Locate the valve stem on the wheel.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Are you having a problem with your wheels or tires?
Asks: What do you notice about your tires?
Description: Valve stems are made out of rubber and are prone to dry out and become brittle. Improperly installed valve stems can also allow air to leak out of the tire. The shrader valve may also become loose, which is a smaller valve inside the stem that holds the air pressure.
InspectionList: 2) Spray the valve stem with  soapy water, or a household cleaner. Inspect the valve stem to see if bubbles form around it.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Are you having a problem with your wheels or tires?
Asks: What do you notice about your tires?
Description: Valve stems are made out of rubber and are prone to dry out and become brittle. Improperly installed valve stems can also allow air to leak out of the tire. The shrader valve may also become loose, which is a smaller valve inside the stem that holds the air pressure.
InspectionList: 3) Use the saopy liquid method to identify a slow leak, if after spraying the valve stem a leak is visible, replace the valve stem.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Are you having a problem with your wheels or tires?
Asks: What do you notice about your tires?
Description: Valve stems are made out of rubber and are prone to dry out and become brittle. Improperly installed valve stems can also allow air to leak out of the tire. The shrader valve may also become loose, which is a smaller valve inside the stem that holds the air pressure.
InspectionList: 4) The Valve Stem may have ruptures or tears at the base, push the side of the stem and listen for a hissing sound. If the sound is heard, the stem is bad and needs to be replaced.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Are you having a problem with your wheels or tires?
Asks: What do you notice about your tires?
Description: A flat tire can happen at any time, Knowing how to change your tire and keeping a regular check on your spare, checking the pressure and quality of the spare, can wind up saving you time, money, and aggravation. Keeping a tire plug kit in your vehicle is also a good way to be prepared incase of a flat. Tire plug kits are inexpensive and can be a life saver on long trips, they come in professional and emergency kits, its a good idea to keep one in your trunk or glove box.
InspectionList: 1) Park your vehicle on a solid, level surface and chock the wheels on the axle that does not have the flat tire. Lift up the vehicle to inspect the tire. Refer to your vehicle owner's manual for proper lifting techniques.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Are you having a problem with your wheels or tires?
Asks: What do you notice about your tires?
Description: A flat tire can happen at any time, Knowing how to change your tire and keeping a regular check on your spare, checking the pressure and quality of the spare, can wind up saving you time, money, and aggravation. Keeping a tire plug kit in your vehicle is also a good way to be prepared incase of a flat. Tire plug kits are inexpensive and can be a life saver on long trips, they come in professional and emergency kits, its a good idea to keep one in your trunk or glove box.
InspectionList: 2) Always secure the vehicle with a jack stand before starting any work. Never rely on the jack itself to hold the vehicle up while working.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Are you having a problem with your wheels or tires?
Asks: What do you notice about your tires?
Description: A flat tire can happen at any time, Knowing how to change your tire and keeping a regular check on your spare, checking the pressure and quality of the spare, can wind up saving you time, money, and aggravation. Keeping a tire plug kit in your vehicle is also a good way to be prepared incase of a flat. Tire plug kits are inexpensive and can be a life saver on long trips, they come in professional and emergency kits, its a good idea to keep one in your trunk or glove box.
InspectionList: 3) Place the transmission in neutral (if necessary) and rotate the tire while you visually inspect the tread and sidewalls for a puncture. The most common causes of tire punctures are nails and glass.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Are you having a problem with your wheels or tires?
Asks: What do you notice about your tires?
Description: A flat tire can happen at any time, Knowing how to change your tire and keeping a regular check on your spare, checking the pressure and quality of the spare, can wind up saving you time, money, and aggravation. Keeping a tire plug kit in your vehicle is also a good way to be prepared incase of a flat. Tire plug kits are inexpensive and can be a life saver on long trips, they come in professional and emergency kits, its a good idea to keep one in your trunk or glove box.
InspectionList: 4) If the puncture is not apparent, fill the tire with air and spray it with soapy water to locate the leak.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Are you having a problem with your wheels or tires?
Asks: What do you notice about your tires?
Description: A flat tire can happen at any time, Knowing how to change your tire and keeping a regular check on your spare, checking the pressure and quality of the spare, can wind up saving you time, money, and aggravation. Keeping a tire plug kit in your vehicle is also a good way to be prepared incase of a flat. Tire plug kits are inexpensive and can be a life saver on long trips, they come in professional and emergency kits, its a good idea to keep one in your trunk or glove box.
InspectionList: 5) Mark the puncture location with chalk.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Are you having a problem with your wheels or tires?
Asks: What do you notice about your tires?
Symptom: Tires screech when turning at low speeds
Description: A  wheel alignment is very important, it keeps the vehicle running smooth and makes sure all the parts of the steering and suspension are working together. When the vehicle is out of alignment it can put stress on other components of the steering and suspension and cause them to wear faster. There are also safety concerns when a vehicle is improperly aligned. When you have suspension related parts replaced you should ask your technician if the vehicle needs to be aligned.
InspectionList: 1) Check the vehicles tires, make sure they are the correct size and  inflated to the correct and equal pressure. The recommmended PSI is stamped on the tire side wall. Inspect all the tires for abnormal wear, signs of the tire balding on the inside or outside edge are a sign that there could be an allignment issue.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Are you having a problem with your wheels or tires?
Asks: What do you notice about your tires?
Symptom: Tires screech when turning at low speeds
Description: A  wheel alignment is very important, it keeps the vehicle running smooth and makes sure all the parts of the steering and suspension are working together. When the vehicle is out of alignment it can put stress on other components of the steering and suspension and cause them to wear faster. There are also safety concerns when a vehicle is improperly aligned. When you have suspension related parts replaced you should ask your technician if the vehicle needs to be aligned.
InspectionList: 2) Check the steering wheel, the wheel should be in the correct twelve O'clock position when driving in a straight line. If the wheel isn't you will want to have the vehicle alligned.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Are you having a problem with your wheels or tires?
Asks: What do you notice about your tires?
Symptom: Tires screech when turning at low speeds
Description: A  wheel alignment is very important, it keeps the vehicle running smooth and makes sure all the parts of the steering and suspension are working together. When the vehicle is out of alignment it can put stress on other components of the steering and suspension and cause them to wear faster. There are also safety concerns when a vehicle is improperly aligned. When you have suspension related parts replaced you should ask your technician if the vehicle needs to be aligned.
InspectionList: 3) Check the vehicle Toe, Toe in meaning the tires are pointing at each other; as if you where to literally point your toes in. Toe out, the tires are facing more away from each other; again literally pointing your toes out is the comparison. To check the toe use a tape measure and an assistant, with the steering wheel in the straight position. Measure the distance of the front tires from center to center of the tire tread on the leading edge and trailing edge of the tires. This should be equal.  The vehicle toe is adjusted by the tie rods and must be equal on both sides.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Are you having a problem with your wheels or tires?
Asks: What do you notice about your tires?
Symptom: Tires screech when turning at low speeds
Description: A  wheel alignment is very important, it keeps the vehicle running smooth and makes sure all the parts of the steering and suspension are working together. When the vehicle is out of alignment it can put stress on other components of the steering and suspension and cause them to wear faster. There are also safety concerns when a vehicle is improperly aligned. When you have suspension related parts replaced you should ask your technician if the vehicle needs to be aligned.
InspectionList: 4) Test drive the vehicle, by driving on a straight level road. Try and feel if the vehicle is pulling it self to the left or right, sometimes it is more noticable when braking. Vibrations can also be caused when the vehicle is out of allignment.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Are you having a problem with your wheels or tires?
Asks: What do you notice about your tires?
Symptom: Tires screech when turning at low speeds
Description: Tire pressure is often overlooked but it directly influences how a vehicle rides on the road. Low tire pressure can affect handling, ride, and fuel economy. Over-inflating tires can cause the vehicle to ride hard, and the tires to wear prematurely. Temperature directly affects tire pressure, check the pressure regularly.
InspectionList: 1) Locate the tires valve stem and remove the valve stem cap.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Are you having a problem with your wheels or tires?
Asks: What do you notice about your tires?
Symptom: Tires screech when turning at low speeds
Description: Tire pressure is often overlooked but it directly influences how a vehicle rides on the road. Low tire pressure can affect handling, ride, and fuel economy. Over-inflating tires can cause the vehicle to ride hard, and the tires to wear prematurely. Temperature directly affects tire pressure, check the pressure regularly.
InspectionList: 2) Using a tire pressure gauge, hold the gauge down on the valve stem to get the tire pressure reading. Perform this step for all tires on the vehicle.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Are you having a problem with your wheels or tires?
Asks: What do you notice about your tires?
Symptom: Tires screech when turning at low speeds
Description: Tire pressure is often overlooked but it directly influences how a vehicle rides on the road. Low tire pressure can affect handling, ride, and fuel economy. Over-inflating tires can cause the vehicle to ride hard, and the tires to wear prematurely. Temperature directly affects tire pressure, check the pressure regularly.
InspectionList: 3) Compare the tire pressure reading you just got to the recommended tire pressure. This is located on the side wall of the tire. The tire pressure is measured in PSI or pounds per square inch. Look for the letters PSI on the tire. Owners manuals also give the tire pressure for the factory installed tires. Some manufacturers also put it on the manufacturers label located in the door jam of the drivers door, it gives the original factory wheel size, tire sizes, tire ratings, and tire pressure.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Are you having a problem with your wheels or tires?
Asks: What do you notice about your tires?
Ask1: What type of abnormal tire wear are you having?
Symptom1: Front tires are wearing on the inside edge
Description: Lack of tire rotations will cause the tire wear to become uneven. Improper tire inflation can also cause uneven tire wear. A worn out shock can also cause the tires to cup. If the wheel alignment is out of spec, it will cause uneven tire wear.
InspectionList: 1) Using a tire tread gauge is the easiest and fastest ways to check your tire treads. You simple place the tread guage inbetween the tire treads and the guage measurse the length of the tread, measure the tire on the inside treads and the outside treads and calculate eny differences you find. If you do not have acces to a tread guage, try using a coin as a reference place the coin inbetween the tire treads, look for obvious differences in the inner and outer treads.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Are you having a problem with your wheels or tires?
Asks: What do you notice about your tires?
Ask1: What type of abnormal tire wear are you having?
Symptom1: Front tires are wearing on the inside edge
Description: Lack of tire rotations will cause the tire wear to become uneven. Improper tire inflation can also cause uneven tire wear. A worn out shock can also cause the tires to cup. If the wheel alignment is out of spec, it will cause uneven tire wear.
InspectionList: 2) Tires wearing faster on the inner or outer edges is a sure sign of a front end problem, Have the wheel alignment checked. This type of wear points to a camber issue, this is the vertical angle of the tires to the road, If the outer edge is worn more then the vehicle has to much positive camber and if the inner edge is worn more the vehicle has to much negative camber. If the inner treads are wearing faster or slower than the outer treads, then check the tire pressure, over-inflated tires will wear down the middle treads faster and under-inflated tires will wear both of the outer edges faster.

InspectionList: 3) Compare the tire pressure reading you just got to the recommended tire pressure. This is located on the side wall of the tire. The tire pressure is measured in PSI or pounds per square inch. Look for the letters PSI on the tire. Owners manuals also give the tire pressure for the factory installed tires. Some manufacturers also put it on the manufacturers label located in the door jam of the drivers door, it gives the original factory wheel size, tire sizes, tire ratings, and tire pressure.

InspectionList: 1) Secure the vehicle on a level surface, making sure the vehicle will not roll or lean too much when jacked up.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Are you having a problem with your wheels or tires?
Asks: What do you notice about your tires?

Description: Tie rod ends are part of the steering system, tie rods are responsible for wheel alignment toe, and steering. Worn tie rod ends can cause abnormal tire wear, front end noise, and wheel shimmy or looseness in steering.
InspectionList: 4) Firmly grasp the tie rod end, push or pull the tie rod end vertical. Feel for any looseness, the tie rod end should feel firm and snug, if the tie rod end moves to easily the tie rod should be replaced. Grinding or binding feeling could mean the tie rod end has rusted internally and should be replaced. Check the rubber boot, if it is damaged water and dirt can easily find its way into the tie rod end, and the tie rod end will wear and need to be replaced.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Are you having a problem with your wheels or tires?
Asks: What do you notice about your tires?
Ask1: What type of abnormal tire wear are you having?
Description: A  wheel alignment is very important, it keeps the vehicle running smooth and makes sure all the parts of the steering and suspension are working together. When the vehicle is out of alignment it can put stress on other components of the steering and suspension and cause them to wear faster. There are also safety concerns when a vehicle is improperly aligned. When you have suspension related parts replaced you should ask your technician if the vehicle needs to be aligned.
InspectionList: 1) Check the vehicles tires, make sure they are the correct size and  inflated to the correct and equal pressure. The recommmended PSI is stamped on the tire side wall. Inspect all the tires for abnormal wear, signs of the tire balding on the inside or outside edge are a sign that there could be an allignment issue.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Are you having a problem with your wheels or tires?
Asks: What do you notice about your tires?
Ask1: What type of abnormal tire wear are you having?
Description: A  wheel alignment is very important, it keeps the vehicle running smooth and makes sure all the parts of the steering and suspension are working together. When the vehicle is out of alignment it can put stress on other components of the steering and suspension and cause them to wear faster. There are also safety concerns when a vehicle is improperly aligned. When you have suspension related parts replaced you should ask your technician if the vehicle needs to be aligned.
InspectionList: 2) Check the steering wheel, the wheel should be in the correct twelve O'clock position when driving in a straight line. If the wheel isn't you will want to have the vehicle alligned.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Are you having a problem with your wheels or tires?
Asks: What do you notice about your tires?
Ask1: What type of abnormal tire wear are you having?
Description: A  wheel alignment is very important, it keeps the vehicle running smooth and makes sure all the parts of the steering and suspension are working together. When the vehicle is out of alignment it can put stress on other components of the steering and suspension and cause them to wear faster. There are also safety concerns when a vehicle is improperly aligned. When you have suspension related parts replaced you should ask your technician if the vehicle needs to be aligned.
InspectionList: 3) Check the vehicle Toe, Toe in meaning the tires are pointing at each other; as if you where to literally point your toes in. Toe out, the tires are facing more away from each other; again literally pointing your toes out is the comparison. To check the toe use a tape measure and an assistant, with the steering wheel in the straight position. Measure the distance of the front tires from center to center of the tire tread on the leading edge and trailing edge of the tires. This should be equal.  The vehicle toe is adjusted by the tie rods and must be equal on both sides.

diagnosing symptom: Are you having a problem with your wheels or tires?
Asks: What do you notice about your tires?

Description: A  wheel alignment is very important, it keeps the vehicle running smooth and makes sure all the parts of the steering and suspension are working together. When the vehicle is out of alignment it can put stress on other components of the steering and suspension and cause them to wear faster. InspectionList: 4) Test drive the vehicle, by driving on a straight level road. Try and feel if the vehicle is pulling it self to the left or right, sometimes it is more noticable when braking. Vibrations can also be caused when the vehicle is out of allignment.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Are you having a problem with your wheels or tires?
Asks: What do you notice about your tires?
Ask1: What type of abnormal tire wear are you having?
Description: Lack of tire rotations will cause the tire wear to become uneven. Improper tire inflation can also cause uneven tire wear. A worn out shock can also cause the tires to cup. If the wheel alignment is out of spec, it will cause uneven tire wear.
InspectionList: 1) Using a tire tread gauge is the easiest and fastest ways to check your tire treads. You simple place the tread guage inbetween the tire treads and the guage measurse the length of the tread, measure the tire on the inside treads and the outside treads and calculate eny differences you find. If you do not have acces to a tread guage, try using a coin as a reference place the coin inbetween the tire treads, look for obvious differences in the inner and outer treads.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Are you having a problem with your wheels or tires?
Asks: What do you notice about your tires?
Ask1: What type of abnormal tire wear are you having?
Description: Lack of tire rotations will cause the tire wear to become uneven. Improper tire inflation can also cause uneven tire wear. A worn out shock can also cause the tires to cup. If the wheel alignment is out of spec, it will cause uneven tire wear.
InspectionList: 2) Tires wearing faster on the inner or outer edges is a sure sign of a front end problem, Have the wheel alignment checked. This type of wear points to a camber issue, this is the vertical angle of the tires to the road, If the outer edge is worn more then the vehicle has to much positive camber and if the inner edge is worn more the vehicle has to much negative camber. If the inner treads are wearing faster or slower than the outer treads, then check the tire pressure, over-inflated tires will wear down the middle treads faster and under-inflated tires will wear both of the outer edges faster.

Symptom1: Flat spots, cupping or various wear all over tire
Description: Shocks control stability when driving and also reduce impact of the road to the rest of the vehicle. Bad shocks can add stress to other suspension parts. Shocks are the most important regular service item in your suspension, regular replacement of your vehicles shocks, because they do wear down over time, can keep other suspension components stronger longer.
InspectionList: 1) Perform a bounce test; using a helper is best, push down on the bumper quickly using a strong effort and release repeat this three times in a row.  If the vehicle free bounces more than 1 and a half times inbetween each push, then the shocks should be replaced. Also a sure sign of bad shocks is the vehicle bottoming out, or floating over bumps. Test drive the vehicle over some speed bumps. If the front or rear feel like they are dropping to hard after crossing the speed bump or the vehicle continues to bounce or "float" for a few seconds then its time to replace the shocks.

Description: Wheel balance can affect the ride of your vehicle, if the wheels are out of balance you may be experiencing a vibration feeling or vibration noise when driving, and sometimes its even stronger at highway speeds. Wheel balancing is done to compensate for heavy spots of  the wheel and tire, if your wheels are bent or chipped this can cause your wheel to be out of balance. Wheel weights are adhered or clipped to the wheel rim to compensate for these differences. Irregular tire wear is also a symptom of a wheel not being balanced.
InspectionList: 1) Secure the vehicle on a level surface, making sure the vehicle will not roll or lean when jacked up.

To properly use the floor jack consult your vehicle owner's manual. The weights are specifically designed for different rim/wheel applications. If performing this procedure on your own, pay close attention to the type of  wheel weights necessary and make sure final readings reach optimum wheel/rim balance.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a hard brake pedal.
Description: Vacuum is responsible for drawing air into the cylinders, it is also responsible for the operation of emissions system, braking system and cruise control system components. Vacuum is transfered through a complex system of rubber hoses and/or plastic tubes. The engine creates a great deal of heat and over time can cause the rubber and plastic hoses to dry out and leak. A vacuum leak can be elusive and take a long time to detect. Common symptoms of a vacuum leak include; vehicle idle fluctuation, hard brake pedal, and a hissing noise heard under the hood.
InspectionList: 1) Open the hood and locate the vacuum hoses. Some Vehicles are equipped with a vacuum hose diagram that can be found under the hood, if not a repair manual is the best way to find were all the vacuum hoses are located for your vehicle. Vacuum hoses are rubber hoses or plastic tubes that operate and control systems such as, emissions,  power brakes, and cruise control. Vacuum leaks can also cause idling and drivability problems.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a hard brake pedal.
Description: Vacuum is responsible for drawing air into the cylinders, it is also responsible for the operation of emissions system, braking system and cruise control system components. Vacuum is transfered through a complex system of rubber hoses and/or plastic tubes. The engine creates a great deal of heat and over time can cause the rubber and plastic hoses to dry out and leak. A vacuum leak can be elusive and take a long time to detect. Common symptoms of a vacuum leak include; vehicle idle fluctuation, hard brake pedal, and a hissing noise heard under the hood.
InspectionList: 2) It may be necessary to use a flashlight in order inspect possible damaged vacuum hoses. Check the vacuum hose that leads to the brake booster for damage or if it is loose.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a hard brake pedal.
Description: Vacuum is responsible for drawing air into the cylinders, it is also responsible for the operation of emissions system, braking system and cruise control system components. Vacuum is transfered through a complex system of rubber hoses and/or plastic tubes. The engine creates a great deal of heat and over time can cause the rubber and plastic hoses to dry out and leak. A vacuum leak can be elusive and take a long time to detect. Common symptoms of a vacuum leak include; vehicle idle fluctuation, hard brake pedal, and a hissing noise heard under the hood.
InspectionList: 3) Continue to inspect for cracked or broken vacuum hoses throughout the engine compartment. Look for worn or disconnected hoses or tubes.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a hard brake pedal.
Description: Vacuum is responsible for drawing air into the cylinders, it is also responsible for the operation of emissions system, braking system and cruise control system components. Vacuum is transfered through a complex system of rubber hoses and/or plastic tubes. The engine creates a great deal of heat and over time can cause the rubber and plastic hoses to dry out and leak. A vacuum leak can be elusive and take a long time to detect. Common symptoms of a vacuum leak include; vehicle idle fluctuation, hard brake pedal, and a hissing noise heard under the hood.
InspectionList: 4) Use a can of carburetor cleaner to spray suspecting hoses. With the vehicle running, spray the hose. If the hose has a leak it will pull the carburetor cleaner in and stabilize the idle for a brief time. If changes are heard after spraying the vacuum hose, it is necessary to replace that particular hose.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a hard brake pedal.
Description: The power brake booster multiplies the force exerted on the master cylinder. A damaged internal diaphragm is the most common reason for brake booster failure. If this problem occurs, the driver will experience a hard brake pedal and have difficulty stopping the vehicle.
InspectionList: 1) With the engine off, relieve the brake booster of all vacuum by pumping the brake pedal several times.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a hard brake pedal.
Description: The power brake booster multiplies the force exerted on the master cylinder. A damaged internal diaphragm is the most common reason for brake booster failure. If this problem occurs, the driver will experience a hard brake pedal and have difficulty stopping the vehicle.
InspectionList: 2) With the brake pedal depressed, start the engine. The brake pedal should sink slightly when the engine starts. If the pedal does not sink, the brake booster has failed or it is not receiving vacuum from the engine.

Specific Answer: I have a hard brake pedal.

InspectionList: 3) Open the hood and locate the brake booster, mounted to the firewall, on the driver side of the engine compartment.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a hard brake pedal.
Description: The power brake booster multiplies the force exerted on the master cylinder. A damaged internal diaphragm is the most common reason for brake booster failure. If this problem occurs, the driver will experience a hard brake pedal and have difficulty stopping the vehicle.
InspectionList: 4) Check for vacuum at the brake booster by pulling the check valve and hose from the booster. Cover the check valve opening with your thumb. If the vacuum is strong, the brake booster will need to be replaced. If the vacuum is weak, inspect the hose and the check valve.

Description: Uneven brake pad wear and rust build up are good indicators of a binding brake caliper. A binding brake caliper can cause the vehicle to pull left or right.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:

InspectionList: 8) There is a rubber seal that is installed around the inside edge of the caliper piston. Check the rubber seal for leaks, tears and condition. This seal is responsible for much of the caliper function and can cause binding if found to be damaged.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:

Description: Loose or worn suspension components will affect vehicle handling and wheel alignment. Loose wheel bearings and worn bushings can cause virbrations, pulling, and increased tire wear.
InspectionList: 9) Use a grease gun and apply grease through the zerk fitting (grease fitting). When the grease begins to ooze from the joint, the boot is full.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Description: Loose or worn suspension components will affect vehicle handling and wheel alignment. Loose wheel bearings and worn bushings can cause virbrations, pulling, and increased tire wear.
InspectionList: 10) Inspect sway bar mounts and end linkage for loose, bent, or missing components. Any damaged linkage will need to be replaced.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Description: Loose or worn suspension components will affect vehicle handling and wheel alignment. Loose wheel bearings and worn bushings can cause virbrations, pulling, and increased tire wear.
InspectionList: 11) Inspect the control arms for damage to the bushings and ball joints. Bushing kits and ball joints are available for replacement; however, replacing the control arm assembly may also be an option.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Description: Loose or worn suspension components will affect vehicle handling and wheel alignment. Loose wheel bearings and worn bushings can cause virbrations, pulling, and increased tire wear.
InspectionList: 12) Inspect the steering rack, steering box, steering column, and the inner tie rod linkage.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Description: Loose or worn suspension components will affect vehicle handling and wheel alignment. Loose wheel bearings and worn bushings can cause virbrations, pulling, and increased tire wear.
InspectionList: 13) Inspect the outer tie rod ends for excessive play at the connection to the steering knuckle. You will also want to inspect the tie rod boots for damage. Note: On some vehicles, it may be necessary to remove the wheels to see and inspect the outer tie rod end.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:

Description: Loose or worn suspension components will affect vehicle handling and wheel alignment. Loose wheel bearings and worn bushings can cause virbrations, pulling, and increased tire wear.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Description: Tire pressure is often overlooked but it directly influences how a vehicle rides on the road. Low tire pressure can affect handling, ride, and fuel economy. Over-inflating tires can cause the vehicle to ride hard, and the tires to wear prematurely. Temperature directly affects tire pressure, check the pressure regularly.
InspectionList: 1) Locate the tires valve stem and remove the valve stem cap.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Description: Tire pressure is often overlooked but it directly influences how a vehicle rides on the road. Low tire pressure can affect handling, ride, and fuel economy. Over-inflating tires can cause the vehicle to ride hard, and the tires to wear prematurely. Temperature directly affects tire pressure, check the pressure regularly.
InspectionList: 2) Using a tire pressure gauge, hold the gauge down on the valve stem to get the tire pressure reading. Perform this step for all tires on the vehicle.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Description: Tire pressure is often overlooked but it directly influences how a vehicle rides on the road. Low tire pressure can affect handling, ride, and fuel economy. Over-inflating tires can cause the vehicle to ride hard, and the tires to wear prematurely. Temperature directly affects tire pressure, check the pressure regularly.
InspectionList: 3) Compare the tire pressure reading you just got to the recommended tire pressure. This is located on the side wall of the tire. The tire pressure is measured in PSI or pounds per square inch. Look for the letters PSI on the tire. Owners manuals also give the tire pressure for the factory installed tires. Some manufacturers also put it on the manufacturers label located in the door jam of the drivers door, it gives the original factory wheel size, tire sizes, tire ratings, and tire pressure.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Description: Brake linings that are contaminated with oil, grease and brake fluid will cause uneven braking. The pads and shoes must be replaced and the source of the contamination repaired. Check for leaking brake calipers, wheel cylinders, grease seals, and axle seals.
InspectionList: 1) Secure your vehicle on a level surface, making sure your car will not roll or lean when jacked up.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Description: Brake linings that are contaminated with oil, grease and brake fluid will cause uneven braking. The pads and shoes must be replaced and the source of the contamination repaired. Check for leaking brake calipers, wheel cylinders, grease seals, and axle seals.
InspectionList: 2) Remove the front wheel hub caps if applicable. Using a tire iron, break loose the front wheel lug nuts but do not remove.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Description: Brake linings that are contaminated with oil, grease and brake fluid will cause uneven braking. The pads and shoes must be replaced and the source of the contamination repaired. Check for leaking brake calipers, wheel cylinders, grease seals, and axle seals.
InspectionList: 3) Using a floor jack, lift up the front of your vehicle.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Description: Brake linings that are contaminated with oil, grease and brake fluid will cause uneven braking. The pads and shoes must be replaced and the source of the contamination repaired. Check for leaking brake calipers, wheel cylinders, grease seals, and axle seals.
InspectionList: 4) Secure the vehicle with jack stands on both sides for safety before starting any work. The pinch welds or the frame rails are the two best locations. Do not rely on the jack to hold the vehicle up while working.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Description: Brake linings that are contaminated with oil, grease and brake fluid will cause uneven braking. The pads and shoes must be replaced and the source of the contamination repaired. Check for leaking brake calipers, wheel cylinders, grease seals, and axle seals.
InspectionList: 5) Remove the front wheel lug nuts. Remove the front wheels and set them aside.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Description: Brake linings that are contaminated with oil, grease and brake fluid will cause uneven braking. The pads and shoes must be replaced and the source of the contamination repaired. Check for leaking brake calipers, wheel cylinders, grease seals, and axle seals.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Description: Brake linings that are contaminated with oil, grease and brake fluid will cause uneven braking. The pads and shoes must be replaced and the source of the contamination repaired. Check for leaking brake calipers, wheel cylinders, grease seals, and axle seals.
InspectionList: 7) Inspect the brake caliper for any signs of binding. Look for dirt built up on the caliper slides or lack of lubricant.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Description: Brake linings that are contaminated with oil, grease and brake fluid will cause uneven braking. The pads and shoes must be replaced and the source of the contamination repaired. Check for leaking brake calipers, wheel cylinders, grease seals, and axle seals.
InspectionList: 8) For drum brakes, remove the brake drum to gain access to the wheel cylinder. Inspect wheel cylinder for fluid leaks or torn cup seals.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Description: Excessive brake lining wear that exposes the brake shoe metal or rivets will score the brake drum surface. This metal-to-metal contact between the shoe and the drum creates a grinding sound.
InspectionList: 1) Park the vehicle on a solid, level surface and chock the front wheels.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Description: Excessive brake lining wear that exposes the brake shoe metal or rivets will score the brake drum surface. This metal-to-metal contact between the shoe and the drum creates a grinding sound.
InspectionList: 2) Remove the rear wheel hub caps if applicable. Using a tire iron or lug nut wrench, break loose the rear wheel lug nuts but do not remove.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Description: Excessive brake lining wear that exposes the brake shoe metal or rivets will score the brake drum surface. This metal-to-metal contact between the shoe and the drum creates a grinding sound.
InspectionList: 3) Lift up the rear of the vehicle with a floor jack.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Description: Excessive brake lining wear that exposes the brake shoe metal or rivets will score the brake drum surface. This metal-to-metal contact between the shoe and the drum creates a grinding sound.
InspectionList: 4) Secure the vehicle with jack stands on both sides for safety before starting any work. The pinch welds or the frame rails are the two best locations. Do not rely on the jack to hold the vehicle up while working.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Description: Excessive brake lining wear that exposes the brake shoe metal or rivets will score the brake drum surface. This metal-to-metal contact between the shoe and the drum creates a grinding sound.
InspectionList: 5) Remove the lug nuts. Remove the rear wheels.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Description: Excessive brake lining wear that exposes the brake shoe metal or rivets will score the brake drum surface. This metal-to-metal contact between the shoe and the drum creates a grinding sound.
InspectionList: 6) If applicable, remove the brake drum retaining clips or screws. Make sure the parking brake is released and mark the drums for installation reference. Remove the brake drums from the hubs or axle flanges.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Description: Excessive brake lining wear that exposes the brake shoe metal or rivets will score the brake drum surface. This metal-to-metal contact between the shoe and the drum creates a grinding sound.
InspectionList: 7) Clean the brake shoes and drums with a water-based solution. Inspect the inside of the drum for grooves, scoring, and heat discoloration.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Description: Excessive brake lining wear that exposes the brake shoe metal or rivets will score the brake drum surface. This metal-to-metal contact between the shoe and the drum creates a grinding sound.
InspectionList: 8) Measure the inside diameter of the drum, at two locations, with a drum micrometer. The measurements should be equal and below the maximum diameter stamped on the drum.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Description: Excessive brake lining wear that exposes the brake shoe metal or rivets will score the brake drum surface. This metal-to-metal contact between the shoe and the drum creates a grinding sound.
InspectionList: 9) Next, carefully inspect the brake shoe linings for wear, heat cracks and fluid contamination. The condition of the linings can often reveal a problem with the brake drums, wheel cylinders, and axle seals.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Description: Excessive brake lining wear that exposes the brake shoe metal or rivets will score the brake drum surface. This metal-to-metal contact between the shoe and the drum creates a grinding sound.
InspectionList: 10) Inspect the brake hardware for damage. Check the wheel cylinders for leaking brake fluid.

InspectionList: 1)  Park the vehicle on a solid, level surface and chock the rear wheels.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:

Description: A grinding noise occurs when the brake pad lining wears and the metal backing is contacting the brake disc (rotor).

diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:

InspectionList: 6) After the wheels have been removed, inspect the brake rotors for scoring, grooves, and heat discoloration. Check the brake rotor thickness with a micrometer and the lateral run-out with a dial indicator. The brake rotor must meet the manufacturer's specifications.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Description: A grinding noise occurs when the brake pad lining wears and the metal backing is contacting the brake disc (rotor).
InspectionList: 7) Inspect the brake pad thickness (1/8 inch minimum) and spin the rotor to check the wear indicator. If you hear a squealing sound, the indicator is contacting the rotor and the pads need replacing. If the pad thickness is okay, remove the calipers and inspect the pad surface for glazing and cracks.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Description: A grinding noise occurs when the brake pad lining wears and the metal backing is contacting the brake disc (rotor).
InspectionList: 8) Inspect the brake calipers for binding, corrosion, and missing or damaged anti-rattle clips or shims. Inspect for brake fluid leaks at the calipers and brake hoses.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Description: If the ABS warning light flashes or remains on after the engine is started, there is a problem with the antilock braking system. If the light is flashing, the ABS is still operating but the system needs attention. If the light is on solid, the ABS system is not operating. The brakes will still function without the ABS, but the vehicle may skid in the event of a sudden stop. Troubleshooting the ABS system may require a scan tool.
InspectionList: 1) Locate your vehicles OBD connection.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Description: If the ABS warning light flashes or remains on after the engine is started, there is a problem with the antilock braking system. If the light is flashing, the ABS is still operating but the system needs attention. If the light is on solid, the ABS system is not operating. The brakes will still function without the ABS, but the vehicle may skid in the event of a sudden stop. Troubleshooting the ABS system may require a scan tool.
InspectionList: 2) Plug your scan tool into the OBD connection with the key in the ON position.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Description: If the ABS warning light flashes or remains on after the engine is started, there is a problem with the antilock braking system. If the light is flashing, the ABS is still operating but the system needs attention. If the light is on solid, the ABS system is not operating. The brakes will still function without the ABS, but the vehicle may skid in the event of a sudden stop. Troubleshooting the ABS system may require a scan tool.
InspectionList: 3) Gather all trouble codes and refer to a vehicle specific service manual for a trouble code index that directs you to the specific component. Refer to our diagnostic trouble coded chart to help you determine your code.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: My brake warning light is on.
Description: If the parking brake is on, the brake warning light will appear on the dash. Make sure the parking brake lever is fully released before driving the vehicle.
InspectionList: 1) Locate the parking brake lever under the dash or on the center console.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: My brake warning light is on.
Description: If the parking brake is on, the brake warning light will appear on the dash. Make sure the parking brake lever is fully released before driving the vehicle.
InspectionList: 2) Release the parking brake lever to verify that it was not engaged. Sometimes the lever may not be fully released.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
