Specific Answer: My brake warning light is on.
Description: The brake warning light may come on If the parking brake switch is damaged or stuck.
InspectionList: 1) Locate the parking brake lever under the dash or on the center console. Make sure the lever is fully released.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: My brake warning light is on.
Description: The brake warning light may come on If the parking brake switch is damaged or stuck.
InspectionList: 2) Remove the center console if applicable.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: My brake warning light is on.
Description: The brake warning light may come on If the parking brake switch is damaged or stuck.
InspectionList: 3) Locate the parking brake switch next to the lever. Verify that the lever is contacting the switch.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: My brake warning light is on.
Description: The brake warning light may come on If the parking brake switch is damaged or stuck.
InspectionList: 4) Disconnect the electrical connector to the switch and turn on the ignition. If the warning light is not on, then the switch is faulty.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: My brake warning light is on.
Description: If the brake fluid is low, the sensor in the master cylinder reservoir will trigger the brake warning light. Worn brake pads or a system leak may be the cause. A brake safety inspection should be performed.
InspectionList: 1) Open the hood and locate the brake master cylinder reservoir on the driver side firewall.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: My brake warning light is on.
Description: If the brake fluid is low, the sensor in the master cylinder reservoir will trigger the brake warning light. Worn brake pads or a system leak may be the cause. A brake safety inspection should be performed.
InspectionList: 2) If the reservoir is clear, check the brake fluid level.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: My brake warning light is on.
Description: If the brake fluid is low, the sensor in the master cylinder reservoir will trigger the brake warning light. Worn brake pads or a system leak may be the cause. A brake safety inspection should be performed.
InspectionList: 3) If the reservoir is not clear, clean the reservoir with a shop towel and remove the cap to inspect the brake fluid level.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a spongy or low brake pedal.
Description: A sinking brake pedal and low fluid levels are symptoms of a defective master cylinder. These symptoms may be caused by internal or external leaks. The master cylinder will wear at a quicker rate if periodic fluid flushes are neglected or if the fluid levels are left out of specification.
InspectionList: 1) Open the hood and locate the brake master cylinder.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a spongy or low brake pedal.
Description: A sinking brake pedal and low fluid levels are symptoms of a defective master cylinder. These symptoms may be caused by internal or external leaks. The master cylinder will wear at a quicker rate if periodic fluid flushes are neglected or if the fluid levels are left out of specification.
InspectionList: 2) After locating the brake master cylinder, remove the fluid reservoir cap and inspect the brake fluid level.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a spongy or low brake pedal.
Description: A sinking brake pedal and low fluid levels are symptoms of a defective master cylinder. These symptoms may be caused by internal or external leaks. The master cylinder will wear at a quicker rate if periodic fluid flushes are neglected or if the fluid levels are left out of specification.
InspectionList: 3) If the brake fluid level is within specification, re-install the cap. Inspect and make sure the reservoir cap does not leak. If it is suspected of leaking, replace the cap.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a spongy or low brake pedal.
Description: A sinking brake pedal and low fluid levels are symptoms of a defective master cylinder. These symptoms may be caused by internal or external leaks. The master cylinder will wear at a quicker rate if periodic fluid flushes are neglected or if the fluid levels are left out of specification.
InspectionList: 4) Step on the brake pedal, and check if the brake pedal gradually sinks all the way down to the floor. If it does, it will be necessary to replace the master cylinder.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a spongy or low brake pedal.
Description: A sinking brake pedal and low fluid levels are symptoms of a defective master cylinder. These symptoms may be caused by internal or external leaks. The master cylinder will wear at a quicker rate if periodic fluid flushes are neglected or if the fluid levels are left out of specification.
InspectionList: 5) Perform a complete visual inspection of the brake master cylinder. Check all attached brake line fittings and directly behind the assembly for fluid leaks. If leaks are suspected, replace the master cylinder.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a spongy or low brake pedal.
Description: Brakes that are not adjusted properly can cause a lower than normal brake pedal.  Most vehicles have self-adjusting brakes, but sometimes the self-adjusters become frozen. If the parking brake does not hold when fully activated, the brakes may need to be adjusted.
InspectionList: 1) Locate the parking brake lever. It can be foot or hand operated.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a spongy or low brake pedal.
Description: Brakes that are not adjusted properly can cause a lower than normal brake pedal.  Most vehicles have self-adjusting brakes, but sometimes the self-adjusters become frozen. If the parking brake does not hold when fully activated, the brakes may need to be adjusted.
InspectionList: 2) Park the vehicle on a slight incline and set the parking brake lever fully.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a spongy or low brake pedal.
Description: Brakes that are not adjusted properly can cause a lower than normal brake pedal.  Most vehicles have self-adjusting brakes, but sometimes the self-adjusters become frozen. If the parking brake does not hold when fully activated, the brakes may need to be adjusted.
InspectionList: 3) Place the vehicle in neutral. If the vehicle creeps or rolls, the brake shoes or parking brake cable needs to be adjusted. The brake shoes must be adjusted before the parking brake cable.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a spongy or low brake pedal.
Description: Brakes that are not adjusted properly can cause a lower than normal brake pedal.  Most vehicles have self-adjusting brakes, but sometimes the self-adjusters become frozen. If the parking brake does not hold when fully activated, the brakes may need to be adjusted.
InspectionList: 4) Park the vehicle on a solid, level surface. Check the parking brake linkage and equalizer for worn parts. Check the movement and condition of the cables.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a spongy or low brake pedal.
Description: Brakes that are not adjusted properly can cause a lower than normal brake pedal.  Most vehicles have self-adjusting brakes, but sometimes the self-adjusters become frozen. If the parking brake does not hold when fully activated, the brakes may need to be adjusted.
InspectionList: 5) Lift up the rear of the vehicle and support it with jack stands. To locate the star wheel adjusters, remove the rubber grommets on the brake drum backing plates.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a spongy or low brake pedal.
Description: Brakes that are not adjusted properly can cause a lower than normal brake pedal.  Most vehicles have self-adjusting brakes, but sometimes the self-adjusters become frozen. If the parking brake does not hold when fully activated, the brakes may need to be adjusted.
InspectionList: 6) Try to move the adjuster with a flat head screw driver. If the adjuster does not move, the rear brakes will need to be inspected and the adjuster repaired.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a spongy or low brake pedal.
Description: Trapped air in the brake system can cause a spongy brake pedal. Air usually enters the system through moisture that is absorbed by the brake fluid. Air can also enter the system during a service procedure or a component failure. If enough air enters the brake system, complete brake failure can occur.
InspectionList: 1) Open the hood and locate the brake master cylinder reservoir on the drivers side next to the firewall.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a spongy or low brake pedal.
Description: Trapped air in the brake system can cause a spongy brake pedal. Air usually enters the system through moisture that is absorbed by the brake fluid. Air can also enter the system during a service procedure or a component failure. If enough air enters the brake system, complete brake failure can occur.
InspectionList: 2) Check the brake fluid levels inside the reservoir. Most brake fluid reservoirs are clear and have a "Min" and "Max" indicator stamped on the side. Always make sure the level is between the indicators.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a spongy or low brake pedal.
Description: Trapped air in the brake system can cause a spongy brake pedal. Air usually enters the system through moisture that is absorbed by the brake fluid. Air can also enter the system during a service procedure or a component failure. If enough air enters the brake system, complete brake failure can occur.
InspectionList: 3) Clean the top of the reservoir and remove the cap. Inspect the color of the brake fluid. If the color is dark, the fluid may be contaminated. Bleeding the brakes is recommended.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a spongy or low brake pedal.
Description: Trapped air in the brake system can cause a spongy brake pedal. Air usually enters the system through moisture that is absorbed by the brake fluid. Air can also enter the system during a service procedure or a component failure. If enough air enters the brake system, complete brake failure can occur.
InspectionList: 4) If the level is below the MIn mark and the fluid is still clear, add the manufacturer's recommended type of brake fluid. DOT 3 is the most common.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a spongy or low brake pedal.
Description: Trapped air in the brake system can cause a spongy brake pedal. Air usually enters the system through moisture that is absorbed by the brake fluid. Air can also enter the system during a service procedure or a component failure. If enough air enters the brake system, complete brake failure can occur.
InspectionList: 5) To check for air in the fluid, place the cap on the reservoir and have an assistant pump the brake pedal several times to pressure the system. Remove the the cap and have the assistant release the pedal. If air is in the system, it will cause the brake fluid to squirt back into the reservoir.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a spongy or low brake pedal.
Description: Trapped air in the brake system can cause a spongy brake pedal. Air usually enters the system through moisture that is absorbed by the brake fluid. Air can also enter the system during a service procedure or a component failure. If enough air enters the brake system, complete brake failure can occur.
InspectionList: 6) Inspect the reservoir cap and seal for damaged.

diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a pulsating brake pedal.
Description: Out-of -round brake drums are often caused by extreme temperature changes during normal braking. An out-of-round drum may look okay to the naked eye, but it can cause gabbing, pulling, and pedal pulsations.
InspectionList: 1) Park the vehicle on a solid, level surface and chock the front wheels.

Description: Out-of -round brake drums are often caused by extreme temperature changes during normal braking. An out-of-round drum may look okay to the naked eye, but it can cause gabbing, pulling, and pedal pulsations.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:

Description: Out-of -round brake drums are often caused by extreme temperature changes during normal braking. An out-of-round drum may look okay to the naked eye, but it can cause gabbing, pulling, and pedal pulsations.
InspectionList: 4) Secure the vehicle with jack stands on both sides for safety before starting any work. The pinch welds or the frame rails are the two best locations. Do not rely on the jack to hold the vehicle up while working.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a pulsating brake pedal.
Description: Out-of -round brake drums are often caused by extreme temperature changes during normal braking. An out-of-round drum may look okay to the naked eye, but it can cause gabbing, pulling, and pedal pulsations.
InspectionList: 5) Remove the lug nuts. Remove the rear wheels.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a pulsating brake pedal.
Description: Out-of -round brake drums are often caused by extreme temperature changes during normal braking. An out-of-round drum may look okay to the naked eye, but it can cause gabbing, pulling, and pedal pulsations.
InspectionList: 6) If applicable, remove the brake drum retaining clips or screws. Make sure the parking brake is released and mark the drums for installation reference. Remove the brake drums from the hubs or axle flanges.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a pulsating brake pedal.
Description: Out-of -round brake drums are often caused by extreme temperature changes during normal braking. An out-of-round drum may look okay to the naked eye, but it can cause gabbing, pulling, and pedal pulsations.
InspectionList: 7) Clean the brake shoes and drums with a water-based solution. Inspect the inside of the drum for grooves, scoring, and heat discoloration.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a pulsating brake pedal.
Description: Out-of -round brake drums are often caused by extreme temperature changes during normal braking. An out-of-round drum may look okay to the naked eye, but it can cause gabbing, pulling, and pedal pulsations.
InspectionList: 8) Measure the inside diameter of the drum, at two locations, with a drum micrometer. The measurements should be equal and below the maximum diameter stamped on the drum.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a pulsating brake pedal.
Description: Out-of -round brake drums are often caused by extreme temperature changes during normal braking. An out-of-round drum may look okay to the naked eye, but it can cause gabbing, pulling, and pedal pulsations.
InspectionList: 9) Next, carefully inspect the brake shoe linings for wear, heat cracks and fluid contamination. The condition of the linings can often reveal a problem with the brake drums, wheel cylinders, and axle seals.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?

Description: Wheel bearings can wear over time because of dirt, lack of lubrication, and improper adjustment. A loose or worn wheel bearing can cause noises and vibrations. It can also affect vehicle handling, braking, and tire wear.
InspectionList: 1) Secure the vehicle on a level surface.

InspectionList: 2) Jack up the vehicle. Every vehicle comes equipped with a jack from the factory. To locate and properly use this jack, see the vehicle owners manual.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a pulsating brake pedal.
Description: Wheel bearings can wear over time because of dirt, lack of lubrication, and improper adjustment. A loose or worn wheel bearing can cause noises and vibrations. It can also affect vehicle handling, braking, and tire wear.
InspectionList: 3) Secure the vehicle with jack stands on both sides for safety before starting any work. Do not rely on the jack to hold the vehicle up while working.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a pulsating brake pedal.
Description: Wheel bearings can wear over time because of dirt, lack of lubrication, and improper adjustment. A loose or worn wheel bearing can cause noises and vibrations. It can also affect vehicle handling, braking, and tire wear.
InspectionList: 4) Spin the tire assembly and listen for any grinding and rumbling noises. A normal wheel bearing should sound uniform as it spins.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a pulsating brake pedal.
Description: Wheel bearings can wear over time because of dirt, lack of lubrication, and improper adjustment. A loose or worn wheel bearing can cause noises and vibrations. It can also affect vehicle handling, braking, and tire wear.
InspectionList: 5) Next, grab the tire at the twelve o'clock and six o'clock position. Try and wobble the tire and wheel back and forth. There should be very little play when doing this. If there is too much play, the wheel bearings could be worn or out of adjustment.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:

Specific Answer: I have a pulsating brake pedal.
Description: A warped brake rotor can be caused by excessive heat or improper wheel lug nut torque. If you feel a pulsation or vibration in the brake pedal, check the rotors for runout and parallelism (thickness variation). Pedal pulsation is normal on vehicles with ABS when the ABS is working.
InspectionList: 1)  Park the vehicle on a solid, level surface and chock the rear wheels.

diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a pulsating brake pedal.
Description: A warped brake rotor can be caused by excessive heat or improper wheel lug nut torque. If you feel a pulsation or vibration in the brake pedal, check the rotors for runout and parallelism (thickness variation). Pedal pulsation is normal on vehicles with ABS when the ABS is working.
InspectionList: 2) Remove the front wheel hub caps if necessary. Using a tire iron or lug nut wrench, loosen the front wheel lug nuts but do not remove.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a pulsating brake pedal.
Description: A warped brake rotor can be caused by excessive heat or improper wheel lug nut torque. If you feel a pulsation or vibration in the brake pedal, check the rotors for runout and parallelism (thickness variation). Pedal pulsation is normal on vehicles with ABS when the ABS is working.
InspectionList: 3) Lift the front of the vehicle with a floor jack.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a pulsating brake pedal.
Description: A warped brake rotor can be caused by excessive heat or improper wheel lug nut torque. If you feel a pulsation or vibration in the brake pedal, check the rotors for runout and parallelism (thickness variation). Pedal pulsation is normal on vehicles with ABS when the ABS is working.
InspectionList: 4) Secure the vehicle with jack stands on both sides for safety before starting any work. The pinch welds or the frame rails are the two best locations. Do not rely on the jack to hold the vehicle up while working.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a pulsating brake pedal.
Description: A warped brake rotor can be caused by excessive heat or improper wheel lug nut torque. If you feel a pulsation or vibration in the brake pedal, check the rotors for runout and parallelism (thickness variation). Pedal pulsation is normal on vehicles with ABS when the ABS is working.
InspectionList: 5) Remove the lug nuts. Remove the front wheels.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a pulsating brake pedal.
Description: A warped brake rotor can be caused by excessive heat or improper wheel lug nut torque. If you feel a pulsation or vibration in the brake pedal, check the rotors for runout and parallelism (thickness variation). Pedal pulsation is normal on vehicles with ABS when the ABS is working.
InspectionList: 6) After the wheels have been removed, inspect the brake rotors for scoring, grooves, and heat discoloration. Check the brake rotor thickness with a micrometer and the lateral run-out with a dial indicator. The brake rotor must meet the manufacturer's specifications.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a pulsating brake pedal.
Description: A warped brake rotor can be caused by excessive heat or improper wheel lug nut torque. If you feel a pulsation or vibration in the brake pedal, check the rotors for runout and parallelism (thickness variation). Pedal pulsation is normal on vehicles with ABS when the ABS is working.
InspectionList: 7) Inspect the brake pad thickness (1/8 inch minimum) and spin the rotor to check the wear indicator. If you hear a squealing sound, the indicator is contacting the rotor and the pads need replacing. If the pad thickness is okay, remove the calipers and inspect the pad surface for glazing and cracks.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What problem are you having with your brakes?
Specific Answer: I have a pulsating brake pedal.
Description: A warped brake rotor can be caused by excessive heat or improper wheel lug nut torque. If you feel a pulsation or vibration in the brake pedal, check the rotors for runout and parallelism (thickness variation). Pedal pulsation is normal on vehicles with ABS when the ABS is working.
InspectionList: 8) Inspect the brake calipers for binding, corrosion, and missing or damaged anti-rattle clips or shims. Inspect for brake fluid leaks at the calipers and brake hoses.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Here are some common interior problems
Description: Fuses become blown from electrical overloads or component malfuntions. Fuses also wear out  when exposed to extreme vibration, or heat.  When performing an electrical system  diagnostic, always start by checking the fuses first. Following this simple step could save you time and money. Your owners manual will have information on the location of the fuse panel and identification of the fuses.
InspectionList: 1) The fuse panel can be located in different locations depending on the manufacturer, check the owners manual for exact location. If you can't find the manual, check for the fuse panel  under the dash board on drivers or passangers side, on the side of the dash, in the glove box, or under the hood in the engine compartment.

Following this simple step could save you time and money. Your owners manual will have information on the location of the fuse panel and identification of the fuses.
InspectionList: 2) Check the back side of the fuse panel cover for a diagram of  the fuses. If not use the owners manual it shoud have labels or a diagram of the fuse panel. Pull out the fuse for the circuit you are testing.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Which lights are you having a problem with?
Asks: Are all of the brake lights out?
Description: Brake light bulbs fail from regular use. It is possible for all of the brake light bulbs to fail at the same time. Before looking for a bad fuse or brake switch, it's a good idea to check for power at the brake light bulb connector. Have an assistant  turn the ignition key on and depress the brake pedal, then test the connector with a test light or simply use a new bulb to see if it works.
InspectionList: 1) Locate the damage brake light bulb. Turn the ignition key to the "on" position.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:

InspectionList: 2) Depress the brake pedal.

InspectionList: 3) Have an assistant inspect your tail lights while you are depressing the brake pedal.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Which lights are you having a problem with?
Asks: What best describes the problem with the headlights?
Description: Headlight bulbs burn out over time from regular use. There are many different types of headlights: incandescent, halogen, and xenon. Incandescent headlights work the same as any light in your home and use a resistor filament to produce light that can break over time. If you have halogen lights It is important when replacing them that you not touch the glass part of the light bulb, because the oils from your skin can actually shorten the life expectancy. Xenon headlights or HID headlights are gas charged bulbs that emit a more intense light; these bulbs are more expensive and last longer.
InspectionList: 1) Open the hood and locate the headlight assembly.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Which lights are you having a problem with?
Asks: What best describes the problem with the headlights?
Description: Headlight bulbs burn out over time from regular use. There are many different types of headlights: incandescent, halogen, and xenon. Incandescent headlights work the same as any light in your home and use a resistor filament to produce light that can break over time. If you have halogen lights It is important when replacing them that you not touch the glass part of the light bulb, because the oils from your skin can actually shorten the life expectancy. Xenon headlights or HID headlights are gas charged bulbs that emit a more intense light; these bulbs are more expensive and last longer.
InspectionList: 2) Locate the headlight selector switch found either on the steering column or on the driver's side dashboard console.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:

If you have halogen lights It is important when replacing them that you not touch the glass part of the light bulb, because the oils from your skin can actually shorten the life expectancy. Xenon headlights or HID headlights are gas charged bulbs that emit a more intense light; these bulbs are more expensive and last longer.
InspectionList: 3) Turn the headlight selector switch to the "ON" position and check to see if the headlight bulbs turn on.

diagnosing symptom: Which lights are you having a problem with?

Description: Headlight bulbs burn out over time from regular use. There are many different types of headlights: incandescent, halogen, and xenon. If you have halogen lights It is important when replacing them that you not touch the glass part of the light bulb, because the oils from your skin can actually shorten the life expectancy. InspectionList: 4) If the headlight bulbs do not turn on, proceed with the inspection. It may be necessary to gain access to the headlight bulb assembly  and inspect it for a sufficient power supply.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Which lights are you having a problem with?

Description: Headlight bulbs burn out over time from regular use. There are many different types of headlights: incandescent, halogen, and xenon. Incandescent headlights work the same as any light in your home and use a resistor filament to produce light that can break over time. If you have halogen lights It is important when replacing them that you not touch the glass part of the light bulb, because the oils from your skin can actually shorten the life expectancy. Xenon headlights or HID headlights are gas charged bulbs that emit a more intense light; these bulbs are more expensive and last longer.
InspectionList: 5) Gain access to the headlight bulb and remove it to expose the power source wire connector.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Which lights are you having a problem with?
Asks: What best describes the problem with the headlights?
Description: Headlight bulbs burn out over time from regular use. There are many different types of headlights: incandescent, halogen, and xenon. Incandescent headlights work the same as any light in your home and use a resistor filament to produce light that can break over time. If you have halogen lights It is important when replacing them that you not touch the glass part of the light bulb, because the oils from your skin can actually shorten the life expectancy. Xenon headlights or HID headlights are gas charged bulbs that emit a more intense light; these bulbs are more expensive and last longer.
InspectionList: 6) After access is gained,  check for power at the power connector using a test light or Digital Volt ohm-meter. Verify that the connector is able to recieve power when the headlight switch is applied.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Which lights are you having a problem with?
Asks: What best describes the problem with the headlights?
Description: Headlight bulbs burn out over time from regular use. There are many different types of headlights: incandescent, halogen, and xenon. Incandescent headlights work the same as any light in your home and use a resistor filament to produce light that can break over time. If you have halogen lights It is important when replacing them that you not touch the glass part of the light bulb, because the oils from your skin can actually shorten the life expectancy. Xenon headlights or HID headlights are gas charged bulbs that emit a more intense light; these bulbs are more expensive and last longer.
InspectionList: 7) If power is not recieved, the problem may at the switch, wiring or at the connector which will require further inspection. If the connector does recieve sufficient power, the problem is with the bulb. Replace the bulb.

Description: There are different types of high beam bulbs. Some bulbs are a combination headlight/ high beam with  dual filaments. Most late model vehicles have seperate high beam and headlights, which are positioned in between the two headlights, and are changed the same way as a headlight bulb.

Description: There are different types of high beam bulbs. Some bulbs are a combination headlight/ high beam with  dual filaments. Most late model vehicles have seperate high beam and headlights, which are positioned in between the two headlights, and are changed the same way as a headlight bulb.
InspectionList: 2) Locate the headlight selector switch found either on the steering column or on the driver's side dashboard console.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Which lights are you having a problem with?
Asks: What best describes the problem with the headlights?
Description: There are different types of high beam bulbs. Some bulbs are a combination headlight/ high beam with  dual filaments. Most late model vehicles have seperate high beam and headlights, which are positioned in between the two headlights, and are changed the same way as a headlight bulb.
InspectionList: 3) Turn the headlight selector switch to the "ON" position and check to see if the headlight bulbs turn on.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Which lights are you having a problem with?
Asks: What best describes the problem with the headlights?
Description: There are different types of high beam bulbs. Some bulbs are a combination headlight/ high beam with  dual filaments. Most late model vehicles have seperate high beam and headlights, which are positioned in between the two headlights, and are changed the same way as a headlight bulb.
InspectionList: 4) If the headlight bulbs do not turn on, proceed with the inspection. It may be necessary to gain access to the headlight bulb assembly  and inspect it for a sufficient power supply.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Which lights are you having a problem with?
Asks: What best describes the problem with the headlights?
Description: There are different types of high beam bulbs. Some bulbs are a combination headlight/ high beam with  dual filaments. Most late model vehicles have seperate high beam and headlights, which are positioned in between the two headlights, and are changed the same way as a headlight bulb.
InspectionList: 5) Gain access to the headlight bulb and remove it to expose the power source wire connector.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Which lights are you having a problem with?
Asks: What best describes the problem with the headlights?
Description: There are different types of high beam bulbs. Some bulbs are a combination headlight/ high beam with  dual filaments. Most late model vehicles have seperate high beam and headlights, which are positioned in between the two headlights, and are changed the same way as a headlight bulb.
InspectionList: 6) After access is gained,  check for power at the power connector using a test light or Digital Volt ohm-meter. Verify that the connector is able to recieve power when the headlight switch is applied.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Which lights are you having a problem with?
Asks: What best describes the problem with the headlights?
Description: There are different types of high beam bulbs. Some bulbs are a combination headlight/ high beam with  dual filaments. Most late model vehicles have seperate high beam and headlights, which are positioned in between the two headlights, and are changed the same way as a headlight bulb.
InspectionList: 7) If power is not recieved, the problem may at the switch, wiring or at the connector which will require further inspection. If the connector does recieve sufficient power, the problem is with the bulb. Replace the bulb.

Symptom: The headlights are not pointing in the correct direction
Description: Headlight assemblies can become moved out of alignment in an accident or if a new assembly is installed, but otherwise they should maintain their position.
InspectionList: 1) Park vehicle on a level grade, facing a wall approximately 25 ft. away from the front of the vehicle.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Which lights are you having a problem with?
Asks: What is the problem you are having with your turn signals?
Symptom: Turn signal, is out or is flashing faster than normal
Description: Turn signal bulbs are a regular wear item. The bulb works the same as an incandescent bulb in your house. Manufacturers are using LED lights as running and turn signal replacements for the old incandescent bulbs. These last longer and use less electricity.
InspectionList: 1) Place the ignition key in the on position.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Which lights are you having a problem with?
Asks: What is the problem you are having with your turn signals?
Symptom: Turn signal, is out or is flashing faster than normal
Description: Turn signal bulbs are a regular wear item. The bulb works the same as an incandescent bulb in your house. Manufacturers are using LED lights as running and turn signal replacements for the old incandescent bulbs. These last longer and use less electricity.
InspectionList: 2) Activate the turn signal switch.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Which lights are you having a problem with?
Asks: What is the problem you are having with your turn signals?
Symptom: Turn signal, is out or is flashing faster than normal
Description: Turn signal bulbs are a regular wear item. The bulb works the same as an incandescent bulb in your house. Manufacturers are using LED lights as running and turn signal replacements for the old incandescent bulbs. These last longer and use less electricity.
InspectionList: 3) If one of the turn signal bulbs is out any additional bulbs may flash faster, the turn signal may stay solid and not blink, or the signal may not come on at all. This is a safety mechanism the vehicle is letting you know there is a turn signal bulb malfunction.

InspectionList: 4) Leaving the turn signal on, step outside the vehicle and check to see which bulb is not working. There is at least one turn signal bulb in the front and rear of every vehicle. Some vehicles are equipped with additional signal bulbs on the side or side view mirror of the vehicle.

Description: Fuses become blown from electrical overloads or component malfuntions. Fuses also wear out  when exposed to extreme vibration, or heat.  When performing an electrical system  diagnostic, always start by checking the fuses first. Following this simple step could save you time and money. Your owners manual will have information on the location of the fuse panel and identification of the fuses.
InspectionList: 1) The fuse panel can be located in different locations depending on the manufacturer, check the owners manual for exact location. If you can't find the manual, check for the fuse panel  under the dash board on drivers or passangers side, on the side of the dash, in the glove box, or under the hood in the engine compartment.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Which lights are you having a problem with?
Asks: What is the problem you are having with your turn signals?
Symptom: None of the turn signals are working
Description: Fuses become blown from electrical overloads or component malfuntions. Fuses also wear out  when exposed to extreme vibration, or heat.  When performing an electrical system  diagnostic, always start by checking the fuses first. Following this simple step could save you time and money. Your owners manual will have information on the location of the fuse panel and identification of the fuses.
InspectionList: 2) Check the back side of the fuse panel cover for a diagram of  the fuses. If not use the owners manual it shoud have labels or a diagram of the fuse panel. Pull out the fuse for the circuit you are testing.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: Which lights are you having a problem with?
Asks: What is the problem you are having with your turn signals?
Symptom: None of the turn signals are working
Description: Fuses become blown from electrical overloads or component malfuntions. Fuses also wear out  when exposed to extreme vibration, or heat.  When performing an electrical system  diagnostic, always start by checking the fuses first. Following this simple step could save you time and money. Your owners manual will have information on the location of the fuse panel and identification of the fuses.
InspectionList: 3) Most vehicle use blade type fuses and can be checked by simply looking through the transparent plastic. There is an internal metal strip that melts when it overheats. Check the strip to see if it has melted.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is the problem with your heat or a/c?
Specific Answer: No hot air when heat is on
Description: A heater core is a small radiator, much like the one under your hood. Heater cores can become clogged over time some common causes for a clogged heater core include; contaminated coolant causing build-up in the cooling system, and the use of stop leak coolant formulas these can at times clog the small holes in the heater core and stop the circulation.
InspectionList: 1) You will need to start the vehicle and allow the engine to warm up to perform this check.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is the problem with your heat or a/c?
Specific Answer: No hot air when heat is on
Description: The thermostat is responsible for keeping the engines minimum operating temperature. The thermostat stays closed until the engine reaches a certain temperature and when it reaches that temperature it opens allowing the coolant to flow from the engine to the radiator and be cooled by the vehicles radiator and fan. If a thermostat is stuck in the closed position it can cause overheating and major engine damage. If a thermostat is stuck open the vehicles engine will not reach its optimal running temperature and over time this can cause engine sludge build up, a common problem associated with an open thermostat is the heating system not getting hot enough.
InspectionList: 1) Open the hood and locate the vehicles upper radiator hose. This hose goes from the radiator to the thermostat housing on the top of the engine.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is the problem with your heat or a/c?
Specific Answer: No hot air when heat is on
Description: The thermostat is responsible for keeping the engines minimum operating temperature. The thermostat stays closed until the engine reaches a certain temperature and when it reaches that temperature it opens allowing the coolant to flow from the engine to the radiator and be cooled by the vehicles radiator and fan. If a thermostat is stuck in the closed position it can cause overheating and major engine damage. If a thermostat is stuck open the vehicles engine will not reach its optimal running temperature and over time this can cause engine sludge build up, a common problem associated with an open thermostat is the heating system not getting hot enough.
InspectionList: 2) If the vehicle is hot allow it to cool before performing this test, if the vehicle is all ready cool start the vehicle. Using an infrared thermometer check the temperature at the upper and lower radiator hose. If you do not have an infrared thermometer you can use your hands to test the temperature of the hoses, make sure to be careful of the moving parts of the engine. After several minutes the hoses should begin to get hot, take note of the upper radiator hose. This hose should all at once begin to warm up letting you know the thermostat has opened and the hot coolant is going from the engine to the radiator to be cooled. If several minutes pass and the hose does not get hot, check the engine temperature inside the vehicle if it is climbing and beginning to over heat shut the vehicle down, the problem is the thermostat is stuck closed.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is the problem with your heat or a/c?
Specific Answer: No hot air when heat is on
Description: A heater control valve regulates the flow of coolant to the heater core, this is what controls the temperature of the heat inside your vehicle. If the fan is working and the heat is not getting hot enough it is possible the valve has stuck or that vacuum to the valve has been lost. Checking your heater control valve for proper operation is a good starting point when diagnosis your heating system.
InspectionList: 1) Start the engine and turn on the heater.

InspectionList: 2) Move the heater temperature switch from cooler to warmer and check for a change in air temperature.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is the problem with your heat or a/c?
Specific Answer: No cold air when A/C is on
Description: The main components of an air conditioning system (A/C) are the compressor, the condenser, the evaporator, and the lines or hoses. The equipment used to detect leaks and charge an A/C system should only be operated by a trained and certified technician.  If your A/C system is not blowing cold air, we recommend taking your vehicle to a certified technician.
InspectionList: 1) Open the hood and locate the vehicles A/C lines or hoses.
Car Problem: No Cold Air A/C Line or Hose

Description: The main components of an air conditioning system (A/C) are the compressor, the condenser, the evaporator, and the lines or hoses. The equipment used to detect leaks and charge an A/C system should only be operated by a trained and certified technician.  If your A/C system is not blowing cold air, we recommend taking your vehicle to a certified technician.
InspectionList: 2) Inspect the A/C lines or hoses for cracks and kinks. Check the hose fittings and mounting bracket locations for wear and leaks.
Car Problem: No Cold Air A/C Line or Hose

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is the problem with your heat or a/c?
Specific Answer: No cold air when A/C is on
Description: The main components of an air conditioning system (A/C) are the compressor, the condenser, the evaporator, and the lines or hoses. The equipment used to detect leaks and charge an A/C system should only be operated by a trained and certified technician.  If your A/C system is not blowing cold air, we recommend taking your vehicle to a certified technician.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is the problem with your heat or a/c?
Specific Answer: No cold air when A/C is on
Description: The main components of an air conditioning system (A/C) are the compressor, the condenser, the evaporator, and the lines or hoses. The equipment used to detect leaks and charge an A/C system should only be operated by a trained and certified technician.  If your A/C system is not blowing cold air, we recommend taking your vehicle to a certified technician.
InspectionList: 2) Inspect the condenser for cracks that would lead to leaking.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is the problem with your heat or a/c?
Specific Answer: No cold air when A/C is on
Description: The main components of an air conditioning system (A/C) are the compressor, the condenser, the evaporator, and the lines or hoses. The equipment used to detect leaks and charge an A/C system should only be operated by a trained and certified technician.  If your A/C system is not blowing cold air, we recommend taking your vehicle to a certified technician.
InspectionList: 1) Open the hood and locate your vehicles A/C compressor. Make sure the engine area has cooled off before inspecting your vehicles belt and A/C compressor to prevent any burns or injury. Use a mirror and a flashlight to inspect hard to access A/C compressors.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is the problem with your heat or a/c?
Specific Answer: No cold air when A/C is on
Description: The main components of an air conditioning system (A/C) are the compressor, the condenser, the evaporator, and the lines or hoses. The equipment used to detect leaks and charge an A/C system should only be operated by a trained and certified technician.  If your A/C system is not blowing cold air, we recommend taking your vehicle to a certified technician.
InspectionList: 2) Check the A/C compressor clutch and pulley, to do this remove the vehicle serpentine or A/C belt. Once the belt is removed spin the A/C compressor pulley, it should feel uniform when spinning. If you notice any grinding, scrapping or it feels loose then it will need to be repaired. If the pulley checks out ok, reinstall the belt.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is the problem with your heat or a/c?
Specific Answer: No cold air when A/C is on
Description: The main components of an air conditioning system (A/C) are the compressor, the condenser, the evaporator, and the lines or hoses. The equipment used to detect leaks and charge an A/C system should only be operated by a trained and certified technician.  If your A/C system is not blowing cold air, we recommend taking your vehicle to a certified technician.
InspectionList: 3) Another check you can perform is while the vehicle is running, leave the hood up and start the vehicle. Turn the A/C on inside the vehicle. Next watch and listen to the vehicle while it is running. The A/C clutch will cycle on and off, listen for changes if you hear a squealing when the compressor clutch engages, the A/C compressor clutch could be wearing out. A click followed by a low spinning noise is the normal operation of the compressor.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is the problem with your heat or a/c?
Specific Answer: The fan speeds are not working properly e.g., High works but the other speeds do not.
Description: The blower motor resistor controls the fan speed for your heating and air conditioning. If ever the speeds are working improperly e.g., low and medium works but high does not, the resistor is most likely the problem.
InspectionList: 1) Turn the ignition key to the run position. It is not necessary to have the vehicle running.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is the problem with your heat or a/c?
Specific Answer: The fan speeds are not working properly e.g., High works but the other speeds do not.
Description: The blower motor resistor controls the fan speed for your heating and air conditioning. If ever the speeds are working improperly e.g., low and medium works but high does not, the resistor is most likely the problem.
InspectionList: 2) Check the fuse for the blower motor circuit at the fuse panel, it should be labeled HVAC or blower motor.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:

Specific Answer: The fan speeds are not working properly e.g., High works but the other speeds do not.
Description: The blower motor resistor controls the fan speed for your heating and air conditioning. If ever the speeds are working improperly e.g., low and medium works but high does not, the resistor is most likely the problem.
InspectionList: 3) Check the blower motor relay (not applicable on all vehicles)

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is the problem with your heat or a/c?
Specific Answer: The fan speeds are not working properly e.g., High works but the other speeds do not.
Description: The blower motor resistor controls the fan speed for your heating and air conditioning. If ever the speeds are working improperly e.g., low and medium works but high does not, the resistor is most likely the problem.
InspectionList: 4) Locate the blower motor and resistor. They will be mounted to the blower housing which is located under the passenger side dash or in the passenger side of the engine compartment attached to the fire wall.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is the problem with your heat or a/c?
Specific Answer: The fan speeds are not working properly e.g., High works but the other speeds do not.
Description: The blower motor resistor controls the fan speed for your heating and air conditioning. If ever the speeds are working improperly e.g., low and medium works but high does not, the resistor is most likely the problem.
InspectionList: 5) Remove the electrical connector at the blower motor, attach a voltmeter to the blower motor connector.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is the problem with your heat or a/c?
Specific Answer: The fan speeds are not working properly e.g., High works but the other speeds do not.
Description: The blower motor resistor controls the fan speed for your heating and air conditioning. If ever the speeds are working improperly e.g., low and medium works but high does not, the resistor is most likely the problem.
InspectionList: 6) Run the heat or A/C through all of the fan speeds, the voltage should change as you go through the fan speeds. The faster the speed the higher the voltage.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is the problem with your heat or a/c?
Specific Answer: The fan speeds are not working properly e.g., High works but the other speeds do not.
Description: The blower motor resistor controls the fan speed for your heating and air conditioning. If ever the speeds are working improperly e.g., low and medium works but high does not, the resistor is most likely the problem.
InspectionList: 7) If there is voltage but the blower is not working, you can test the blower motor by using jumper wires. Connect a jumper wire to the motor ground terminal and a good ground and another jumper wire to the positive terminal on the battery and touch it to the positive terminal on the blower motor. If the blower motor spins, there is a chance the circuit has a bad ground. If the Motor does not spin, the blower motor is faulty.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is the problem with your heat or a/c?
Specific Answer: The fan speeds are not working properly e.g., High works but the other speeds do not.
Description: The blower motor resistor controls the fan speed for your heating and air conditioning. If ever the speeds are working improperly e.g., low and medium works but high does not, the resistor is most likely the problem.
InspectionList: 8) If there is no voltage at all or at certain fan speeds then unplug the connector to the resistor and check the pins for voltage. If there is voltage at the pins then the resistor is faulty. You can also check the resistor by removing it and checking it for continuity across the resistors.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is the problem with your heat or a/c?
Specific Answer: The fan speeds are not working properly e.g., High works but the other speeds do not.
Description: The blower motor resistor controls the fan speed for your heating and air conditioning. If ever the speeds are working improperly e.g., low and medium works but high does not, the resistor is most likely the problem.
InspectionList: 9) If there is no voltage going to the resitor then remove the heater and A/C control and check for voltage into and out of the control. If there is voltage to the control but not going to the resistor then the control is faulty.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is the problem with your heat or a/c?
Description: Fuses become blown from electrical overloads or component malfuntions. Fuses also wear out  when exposed to extreme vibration, or heat.  When performing an electrical system  diagnostic, always start by checking the fuses first. Following this simple step could save you time and money. Your owners manual will have information on the location of the fuse panel and identification of the fuses.
InspectionList: 1) The fuse panel can be located in different locations depending on the manufacturer, check the owners manual for exact location. If you can't find the manual, check for the fuse panel  under the dash board on drivers or passangers side, on the side of the dash, in the glove box, or under the hood in the engine compartment.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is the problem with your heat or a/c?
Description: Fuses become blown from electrical overloads or component malfuntions. Fuses also wear out  when exposed to extreme vibration, or heat.  When performing an electrical system  diagnostic, always start by checking the fuses first. Following this simple step could save you time and money. Your owners manual will have information on the location of the fuse panel and identification of the fuses.
InspectionList: 2) Check the back side of the fuse panel cover for a diagram of  the fuses. If not use the owners manual it shoud have labels or a diagram of the fuse panel. Pull out the fuse for the circuit you are testing.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is the problem with your heat or a/c?
Description: Fuses become blown from electrical overloads or component malfuntions. Fuses also wear out  when exposed to extreme vibration, or heat.  When performing an electrical system  diagnostic, always start by checking the fuses first. Following this simple step could save you time and money. Your owners manual will have information on the location of the fuse panel and identification of the fuses.
InspectionList: 3) Most vehicle use blade type fuses and can be checked by simply looking through the transparent plastic. There is an internal metal strip that melts when it overheats. Check the strip to see if it has melted.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is the problem with your heat or a/c?
Specific Answer: Windshield fogs up with the defroster setting on
Description: A heater core is a small  scaled down version of the radiator in the front of your vehicle. The heater core is located inside your vehicle in the dash on the passenger side inside of the blower case. They can wear down over time from heat expansion and corrosion. If your windows are fogging up when you put on the defroster there is a good chance the heater core is to blame. A small leak in the heater core will give off a steam that can cause your windows to fog and is usually accompanied with a sweet coolant /antifreeze smell.
InspectionList: 1) Open the hood locate and remove the radiator cap

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is the problem with your heat or a/c?
Specific Answer: Windshield fogs up with the defroster setting on
Description: A heater core is a small  scaled down version of the radiator in the front of your vehicle. The heater core is located inside your vehicle in the dash on the passenger side inside of the blower case. They can wear down over time from heat expansion and corrosion. If your windows are fogging up when you put on the defroster there is a good chance the heater core is to blame. A small leak in the heater core will give off a steam that can cause your windows to fog and is usually accompanied with a sweet coolant /antifreeze smell.
InspectionList: 2) Connect the pressure tester to the radiator filler. Pumping the pressure tester raise the pressure to the rating that is on the radiator cap.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What is the problem with your heat or a/c?
Specific Answer: Windshield fogs up with the defroster setting on
Description: A heater core is a small  scaled down version of the radiator in the front of your vehicle. The heater core is located inside your vehicle in the dash on the passenger side inside of the blower case. They can wear down over time from heat expansion and corrosion. If your windows are fogging up when you put on the defroster there is a good chance the heater core is to blame. A small leak in the heater core will give off a steam that can cause your windows to fog and is usually accompanied with a sweet coolant /antifreeze smell.
InspectionList: 3) Watch the gauge on the pressure tester it should be able to hold the pressure for 12-15 minutes, if the gauge starts to fall immediately there is a system leak. Visually inspect the vehicle for coolant leaks. Check the radiator, water pump, coolant tank, radiator hoses, and check under the vehicle for drips that you can follow back to the location of the leak. Also check inside the vehicle, the heater core is located inside the dash on the passengers side, check the front passenger floor for dampness, also look under passenger side dash for any signs of a coolant leak.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What steering or handling problem are you having?
Description: Brake calipers will usually bind on the slides from being improperly lubed or overly dirty. Gunk builds up on the slides and will not allow the caliper to press together, preventing the pads from stopping the rotor from spinning.
InspectionList: 1) Secure your vehicle on a level surface, making sure your car will not roll or lean when jacked up.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What steering or handling problem are you having?
Description: Brake calipers will usually bind on the slides from being improperly lubed or overly dirty. Gunk builds up on the slides and will not allow the caliper to press together, preventing the pads from stopping the rotor from spinning.
InspectionList: 2) Remove the front wheel hub caps if applicable. Using a tire iron, break loose the front wheel lug nuts but do not remove.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What steering or handling problem are you having?
Description: Brake calipers will usually bind on the slides from being improperly lubed or overly dirty. Gunk builds up on the slides and will not allow the caliper to press together, preventing the pads from stopping the rotor from spinning.
InspectionList: 3) Using a floor jack, lift up the front of your vehicle.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What steering or handling problem are you having?
Description: Brake calipers will usually bind on the slides from being improperly lubed or overly dirty. Gunk builds up on the slides and will not allow the caliper to press together, preventing the pads from stopping the rotor from spinning.
InspectionList: 4) Secure the vehicle with jack stands on both sides for safety before starting any work. The pinch welds or the frame rails are the two best locations. Do not rely on the jack to hold the vehicle up while working.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What steering or handling problem are you having?
Description: Brake calipers will usually bind on the slides from being improperly lubed or overly dirty. Gunk builds up on the slides and will not allow the caliper to press together, preventing the pads from stopping the rotor from spinning.
InspectionList: 5) Remove the front wheel lug nuts. Remove the front wheels and set them aside.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What steering or handling problem are you having?
Description: Brake calipers will usually bind on the slides from being improperly lubed or overly dirty. Gunk builds up on the slides and will not allow the caliper to press together, preventing the pads from stopping the rotor from spinning.
InspectionList: 6) Repeat steps 2 through 4 to remove the rear wheels.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What steering or handling problem are you having?
Description: Brake calipers will usually bind on the slides from being improperly lubed or overly dirty. Gunk builds up on the slides and will not allow the caliper to press together, preventing the pads from stopping the rotor from spinning.
InspectionList: 7) Inspect the brake caliper for any signs of binding. Look for dirt built up on the caliper slides or lack of lubricant.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What steering or handling problem are you having?
Description: Brake calipers will usually bind on the slides from being improperly lubed or overly dirty. Gunk builds up on the slides and will not allow the caliper to press together, preventing the pads from stopping the rotor from spinning.
InspectionList: 8) For drum brakes, remove the brake drum to gain access to the wheel cylinder. Inspect wheel cylinder for fluid leaks or torn cup seals.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What steering or handling problem are you having?
Description: A  wheel alignment is very important, it keeps the vehicle running smooth and makes sure all the parts of the steering and suspension are working together. When the vehicle is out of alignment it can put stress on other components of the steering and suspension and cause them to wear faster. There are also safety concerns when a vehicle is improperly aligned. When you have suspension related parts replaced you should ask your technician if the vehicle needs to be aligned.
InspectionList: 1) Check the vehicles tires, make sure they are the correct size and  inflated to the correct and equal pressure. The recommmended PSI is stamped on the tire side wall. Inspect all the tires for abnormal wear, signs of the tire balding on the inside or outside edge are a sign that there could be an allignment issue.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What steering or handling problem are you having?
Description: A  wheel alignment is very important, it keeps the vehicle running smooth and makes sure all the parts of the steering and suspension are working together. When the vehicle is out of alignment it can put stress on other components of the steering and suspension and cause them to wear faster. There are also safety concerns when a vehicle is improperly aligned. When you have suspension related parts replaced you should ask your technician if the vehicle needs to be aligned.
InspectionList: 2) Check the steering wheel, the wheel should be in the correct twelve O'clock position when driving in a straight line. If the wheel isn't you will want to have the vehicle alligned.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What steering or handling problem are you having?
Description: A  wheel alignment is very important, it keeps the vehicle running smooth and makes sure all the parts of the steering and suspension are working together. When the vehicle is out of alignment it can put stress on other components of the steering and suspension and cause them to wear faster. There are also safety concerns when a vehicle is improperly aligned. When you have suspension related parts replaced you should ask your technician if the vehicle needs to be aligned.
InspectionList: 3) Check the vehicle Toe, Toe in meaning the tires are pointing at each other; as if you where to literally point your toes in. Toe out, the tires are facing more away from each other; again literally pointing your toes out is the comparison. To check the toe use a tape measure and an assistant, with the steering wheel in the straight position. Measure the distance of the front tires from center to center of the tire tread on the leading edge and trailing edge of the tires. This should be equal.  The vehicle toe is adjusted by the tie rods and must be equal on both sides.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What steering or handling problem are you having?
Description: A  wheel alignment is very important, it keeps the vehicle running smooth and makes sure all the parts of the steering and suspension are working together. When the vehicle is out of alignment it can put stress on other components of the steering and suspension and cause them to wear faster. There are also safety concerns when a vehicle is improperly aligned. When you have suspension related parts replaced you should ask your technician if the vehicle needs to be aligned.
InspectionList: 4) Test drive the vehicle, by driving on a straight level road. Try and feel if the vehicle is pulling it self to the left or right, sometimes it is more noticable when braking. Vibrations can also be caused when the vehicle is out of allignment.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What steering or handling problem are you having?
Description: Tire pressure is often overlooked but it directly influences how a vehicle rides on the road. Low tire pressure can affect handling, ride, and fuel economy. Over-inflating tires can cause the vehicle to ride hard, and the tires to wear prematurely. Temperature directly affects tire pressure, check the pressure regularly.
InspectionList: 1) Locate the tires valve stem and remove the valve stem cap.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What steering or handling problem are you having?
Description: Tire pressure is often overlooked but it directly influences how a vehicle rides on the road. Low tire pressure can affect handling, ride, and fuel economy. Over-inflating tires can cause the vehicle to ride hard, and the tires to wear prematurely. Temperature directly affects tire pressure, check the pressure regularly.
InspectionList: 2) Using a tire pressure gauge, hold the gauge down on the valve stem to get the tire pressure reading. Perform this step for all tires on the vehicle.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What steering or handling problem are you having?
Description: Tire pressure is often overlooked but it directly influences how a vehicle rides on the road. Low tire pressure can affect handling, ride, and fuel economy. Over-inflating tires can cause the vehicle to ride hard, and the tires to wear prematurely. Temperature directly affects tire pressure, check the pressure regularly.
InspectionList: 3) Compare the tire pressure reading you just got to the recommended tire pressure. This is located on the side wall of the tire. The tire pressure is measured in PSI or pounds per square inch. Look for the letters PSI on the tire. Owners manuals also give the tire pressure for the factory installed tires. Some manufacturers also put it on the manufacturers label located in the door jam of the drivers door, it gives the original factory wheel size, tire sizes, tire ratings, and tire pressure.

Description: Wheel balance can affect the ride of your vehicle, if the wheels are out of balance you may be experiencing a vibration feeling or vibration noise when driving, and sometimes its even stronger at highway speeds. Wheel balancing is done to compensate for heavy spots of  the wheel and tire, if your wheels are bent or chipped this can cause your wheel to be out of balance. Wheel weights are adhered or clipped to the wheel rim to compensate for these differences. Irregular tire wear is also a symptom of a wheel not being balanced.
InspectionList: 1) Secure the vehicle on a level surface, making sure the vehicle will not roll or lean when jacked up.
Car Problem: Tires/Wheels Out of Balance or Damaged.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:

Wheel weights are adhered or clipped to the wheel rim to compensate for these differences. Irregular tire wear is also a symptom of a wheel not being balanced.
InspectionList: 2) Use a floor jack to lift the vehicle. Most vehicles are equipped with a factory floor jack commonly located in the trunk. To properly use the floor jack consult your vehicle owner's manual. Following the owner's manual instructions will give the correct location to jack the vehicle up and the the proper operation of the jack.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What steering or handling problem are you having?
Specific Answer: My steering wheel is hard to turn
Description: A serpentine belt is a rubber belt that is driven by pulleys connected to the engine, the belt then runs motors and pumps that are necessary to help keep your vehicle running. When your serpentine belt begins to make noise or is noticebly worn or damaged, its time to replace it. A bad serpentine belt can cause your vehicle to stall, steering to tighten up, and even overheat your vehicle.
InspectionList: 1) Open the vehicles hood and locate the vehicles serpentine belt.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What steering or handling problem are you having?
Specific Answer: My steering wheel is hard to turn
Description: A serpentine belt is a rubber belt that is driven by pulleys connected to the engine, the belt then runs motors and pumps that are necessary to help keep your vehicle running. When your serpentine belt begins to make noise or is noticebly worn or damaged, its time to replace it. A bad serpentine belt can cause your vehicle to stall, steering to tighten up, and even overheat your vehicle.
InspectionList: 2) Inspect the ribs on the serpentine belt. Check for cracks in the rubber, fraying, or chips to the belt. Look for signs of fluids that may have spilled on the belt.

Describing the Symptoms: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
diagnosing symptom: What steering or handling problem are you having?
Specific Answer: My steering wheel is hard to turn
Description: A serpentine belt is a rubber belt that is driven by pulleys connected to the engine, the belt then runs motors and pumps that are necessary to help keep your vehicle running. When your serpentine belt begins to make noise or is noticebly worn or damaged, its time to replace it. A bad serpentine belt can cause your vehicle to stall, steering to tighten up, and even overheat your vehicle.
InspectionList: 3) Check the belt tension by pushing down in the middle of a section of the belt. It should not move more than a half inch. Look at the smooth side of the belt if it looks glazed, like it has a shine to it, the belt is probably loose and slipping on the pulleys.
